chunks.content: A covered call is created by owning 100 shares of stock and selling 1 call option against those shares. The 'covered' aspect means your obligation to deliver shares is covered by your existing position. Key mechanics: (1) Collect premium upfront - this is yours to keep regardless of outcome. (2) Strike selection determines your max profit - shares get called away at strike price if ITM at expiration. (3) Breakeven = stock purchase price - premium received. (4) Best used when: slightly bullish, expecting sideways movement, or willing to sell at strike price. Risk: Unlimited downside on stock minus the premium collected. Max profit: (Strike - Stock Price) + Premium.

Strike selection for covered calls follows these TastyTrade research findings: (1) Delta 0.30-0.35 strikes offer optimal risk/reward - 65-70% probability of profit with meaningful premium. (2) ATM strikes maximize premium but high assignment risk. (3) OTM strikes (delta 0.20-0.25) provide more upside room but less premium. (4) Consider cost basis - sell strikes above your cost basis to ensure profit if assigned. (5) IV Rank above 30 is ideal for selling premium. Research shows delta 0.30 strikes outperform over thousands of occurrences due to positive theta decay and reasonable probability of keeping shares.

IV Rank measures where current implied volatility sits relative to its 52-week range. Formula: IV Rank = (Current IV - 52-week Low IV) / (52-week High IV - 52-week Low IV) * 100. Interpretation: IV Rank 0% = IV at 52-week low (options cheap). IV Rank 50% = IV at midpoint. IV Rank 100% = IV at 52-week high (options expensive). Trading implications: IV Rank > 50% = Sell premium (options overpriced, likely to contract). IV Rank < 30% = Buy premium or avoid selling (options fairly priced). IV Rank is superior to raw IV because it contextualizes volatility relative to the specific underlying's history.

IV Percentile counts the percentage of days over the past year where IV was lower than current IV. Example: IV Percentile of 80% means IV was lower than today 80% of the time in the past year. Key difference from IV Rank: IV Rank uses the range (high-low), IV Percentile uses frequency distribution. IV Percentile is less sensitive to one-time IV spikes. TastyTrade prefers IV Rank for entry decisions but both metrics are valuable. Use IV Rank > 50% AND IV Percentile > 50% for highest conviction premium selling setups.

A bull put spread (put credit spread) is constructed by: (1) Selling an OTM put at higher strike. (2) Buying a further OTM put at lower strike. Max profit = Credit received (when underlying stays above short strike at expiration). Max loss = Width of spread - Credit received (when underlying below long strike). Breakeven = Short strike - Credit received. Probability of profit = 100% - Delta of short strike. Example: Stock at $100, sell $95 put for $2.00, buy $90 put for $0.75. Net credit = $1.25. Max profit = $125. Max loss = $500 - $125 = $375. Ideal conditions: Bullish bias, IV Rank > 30%, 30-45 DTE.

A bear call spread (call credit spread) is constructed by: (1) Selling an OTM call at lower strike. (2) Buying a further OTM call at higher strike. Max profit = Credit received (when underlying stays below short strike). Max loss = Width of spread - Credit received (when underlying above long strike). Breakeven = Short strike + Credit received. Use when: Bearish bias or expecting sideways movement. Advantage over naked calls: Defined risk, lower margin requirement. Width selection: $5-wide spreads for stocks under $100, $10-wide for stocks over $100. Collect at least 1/3 width of spread in premium for favorable risk/reward.

An iron condor combines a bull put spread and bear call spread on the same underlying with same expiration. Construction: (1) Sell OTM put (e.g., delta 0.16). (2) Buy further OTM put (define risk). (3) Sell OTM call (e.g., delta 0.16). (4) Buy further OTM call (define risk). Max profit = Total credit received (when price stays between short strikes). Max loss = Width of widest spread - Total credit. Sweet spot: High IV Rank (>50%), low expected movement, 30-45 DTE. Manage at 50% max profit or 21 DTE (whichever comes first). Research shows managing winners early (50% profit) increases overall profitability significantly.

The Wheel is a systematic income strategy alternating between cash-secured puts and covered calls. Cycle: (1) START: Sell cash-secured put on stock you want to own at strike below current price. (2) If assigned (put ITM at expiration): Now own 100 shares at strike price minus premium. (3) ROTATE: Sell covered call against shares at strike above your cost basis. (4) If called away (call ITM at expiration): Sold shares at strike, keep premium. Return to step 1. (5) If not called away: Repeat covered call sales. Key: Only wheel stocks you genuinely want to own. The strategy works best with high-quality stocks that pay dividends. Collect premium in both phases while waiting for desired entry/exit prices.

Theta (time decay) accelerates as expiration approaches. Key findings from TastyTrade research: (1) Theta decay is non-linear - accelerates in final 30 days. (2) ATM options have highest theta. (3) OTM/ITM options have lower theta but decay rates converge near expiration. (4) 45 DTE is optimal entry for premium sellers - captures steepest decay curve. (5) Managing at 21 DTE avoids gamma risk spike. (6) Weekend theta: Options lose 2-3 days of theta over weekends (Friday close to Monday open). Strategy: Enter 30-45 DTE, exit at 21 DTE or 50% profit. This captures the 'sweet spot' of theta decay while avoiding late-cycle gamma exposure.

Delta serves as a probability proxy and position sizing guide. Interpretations: (1) Delta 0.30 call = ~30% probability of being ITM at expiration. (2) Short delta 0.16 put = ~84% probability of profit. (3) Portfolio delta = Directional exposure in share equivalents. Position sizing rules: (1) Keep portfolio delta between -0.10 to +0.10 beta-weighted to SPY for neutral stance. (2) Each position should contribute < 5% to portfolio delta. (3) Adjust positions when delta drifts >50% from original. (4) Roll untested side to collect more premium and rebalance delta. Delta-neutral trading reduces directional risk and focuses on collecting theta.

Gamma measures rate of change in delta. Critical for short premium sellers: (1) Gamma is highest for ATM options. (2) Gamma spikes dramatically in final 5-7 days to expiration. (3) High gamma = Large delta swings for small price moves. (4) Short gamma position (sold options) faces amplified losses if underlying moves against you. Risk mitigation: (1) Close or roll positions by 21 DTE to avoid gamma spike. (2) Avoid ATM strikes in final week. (3) Never hold short options through binary events (earnings) in final days. (4) Gamma is your enemy when short options - manage it actively. Research shows closing at 50% profit regardless of DTE outperforms holding to expiration.

Vega measures sensitivity to changes in implied volatility. Key concepts: (1) Long options = Long vega (benefit from IV increase). (2) Short options = Short vega (benefit from IV decrease). (3) Vega is highest for ATM options and decreases for ITM/OTM. (4) Longer-dated options have higher vega. Trading implications: Sell premium when IV Rank > 50% because IV mean reverts. IV contraction after entry benefits short vega positions. Earnings plays: IV typically inflates before earnings and collapses after (IV crush). Selling premium before earnings captures IV crush but faces event risk. Vega risk is often underestimated - a 10-point IV drop can significantly impact position P/L even without underlying movement.

TastyTrade position sizing guidelines: (1) Risk no more than 1-5% of portfolio on any single trade. (2) For defined risk trades (spreads), max loss should be < 5% of portfolio. (3) For undefined risk (naked options), use notional value: position notional < 5% of portfolio. (4) Diversify across 10-20 positions minimum. (5) Diversify across sectors and correlation groups. (6) Keep 50% of portfolio in cash/buying power for adjustments. (7) Portfolio-level: Cap total delta exposure, monitor beta-weighted Greeks. (8) Scaling: Start small (1-2% risk), scale up as strategies prove profitable. Position sizing is the #1 risk management tool - oversizing kills accounts faster than bad trades.

Rolling = Closing current position and opening new one in single transaction. Types: (1) Roll out: Same strike, later expiration (extend duration). (2) Roll up/down: Different strike, same/later expiration (adjust directional bias). (3) Roll out and up/down: Combine both adjustments. When to roll: (1) Tested side (strike breached) to collect more premium and give position more time. (2) Untested side to capture additional credit and rebalance. (3) When IV increases (can roll for credit despite adverse move). Rolling rules: (1) Only roll for a credit - never pay to roll. (2) Roll early (before strikes are deeply breached). (3) Don't roll indefinitely - accept loss if position is broken. (4) Rolling up/down should improve probability of profit.

Earnings events create predictable IV patterns: (1) IV inflates 2-3 weeks before earnings. (2) IV collapses immediately after announcement (IV crush). (3) Expected move pricing: Market prices in expected move via options premiums. Strategies: (1) Pre-earnings IV expansion: Buy straddles/strangles 2-3 weeks out if IV Rank < 30%. (2) Earnings premium selling: Sell strangles/iron condors right before earnings to capture IV crush. (3) Post-earnings drift: Direction often continues 1-2 weeks after earnings. Risks: Earnings moves can exceed expected move - undefined risk strategies face gap risk. Research shows: Selling premium around earnings is profitable long-term but requires strict position sizing (1-2% risk per trade).

Probability of OTM (P.OTM) = Probability option expires worthless (profit for sellers). Calculation: P.OTM for calls = 1 - Delta. P.OTM for puts = 1 - |Delta|. TastyTrade findings: (1) Selling options with P.OTM > 70% has positive expectancy. (2) Managing winners at 50% profit increases win rate to >80%. (3) Higher P.OTM = Less premium but higher success rate. (4) Sweet spot: 70-85% P.OTM (delta 0.15-0.30) balances premium and probability. Trade-off: High P.OTM (>90%) has tiny premium - not worth the risk. Low P.OTM (<60%) has premium but negative expectancy long-term. Mechanical approach: Sell at P.OTM 70%, manage at 50% profit or 21 DTE.
